comments: Breakout room discussions
All live lectures are recorded for future reference.
Last 15-20 minutes, small group discussions

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course taught me topics in combinatorics like posets and generating functions.
Applications of power series to counting problems, graph theory counting, concepts in posets, etc.
I learnt about fundamental frameworks of enumerative combinatorics and a lot of interesting combinatoric examples/problems.
This course taught a lot of useful counting techniques, as well as introduced posets.
I learned a lot about common themes in modern combinatorics and new concepts used to describe them. It was very exploratory.

Topics including generating functions, permutations, multisets, stirling numbers, partitions, exponential generating functions, principle of inclusion-exclusion, poset theory. Learned combinatorial vs algebraic proofs. Explored interesting problems like counting Dyck paths and lattice paths.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course is great. I love how Prof Kenyon elaborate the ideas and give brief introcustion to some topics in his own research.

The course's material was challenging but still easy to follow. The workload spread evenly throughout the semester so I never feel stressful about the course. The final project and presentation were an amazing opportunity for us to research about the aspect of combinatorics that we are interested in and learn from others students' interests as well.

The lectures for this course were really great. Professor Kenyon's teaching style is really easy to follow, and he paid attention to students when we were confused. Some math professors use the online format to cram as much information as possible into lecture, but Professor Kenyon did a great job presenting the material at a pace that everyone could understand. When I signed up for the course, I thought it would be more about graph theory than it ended up being.

I think it would have been much more helpful if we had a teaching assistant offering more drop-in office hours. Sometimes the homework would get difficult, but there would be no one to go to for help. However, Professor Kenyon's weekly office hours were very helpful, even though I wish it could have been offered more frequently instead of just the same time slot every week. I also think the problem sets could have been graded more promptly so we can receive feedback sooner than late.
The course overall was well taught. Some topics are not easy but very interesting. Professor Kenyon is a very nice teacher.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course goes well under remote learning mode.
The final presentations were a great way to expose us to several combinatorics topics in a short period of time, but breakout rooms during lectures failed to provide enough problem solving practice.

The recorded videos were always uploaded quickly after the class ended. Professor Kenyon uses a handwritten note taking app so I can still feel the linear flow during the lecture just like when we use chalkboard, which makes it easy to follow the lecture.

The use of the electronic notepad was really helpful. He could just scroll up if someone had a question about what was covered in a previous lecture. I think that the breakout rooms for working on problems was a good idea.

The recorded lectures were great. Professor Kenyon adapted well by presenting with an iPad. Sometimes, breakout-room discussions would be a little hard because many students only have pen and paper, instead of an iPad. I also think there could have been more office hours.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to students who is interested in combinatorial skills. This course is of great interest to me. I would say if you enjoy taking MATH 244 discrete math, you would probably love this course as well.
Probably not, honestly.  It wasn't the hardest math class I've taken, but the content was pretty dull.  In weeks with really hard psets, there was pretty much no way to get help.
This is a great combinatorics course. I definitely recommend it.

The lectures for this course were really great. Professor Kenyon's teaching style is really easy to follow, and he paid attention to students when we were confused. Some math professors use the online format to cram as much information as possible into lecture, but Professor Kenyon did a great job presenting the material at a pace that everyone could understand. When I signed up for the course, I thought it would be more about graph theory than it ended up being. It ended up being more about counting techniques in general and about posets.
Yes, so long as they are prepared to do challenging psets every week.
If you enjoyed discrete math and would like more exposure to the applications and methods of combinatorics, yes.

Yes, if youre comfortable with proof writing and have a year or two of university math under your belt. No real foundations required but otherwise the pace might be overwhelming. Midterm is take-home and final is a project, very refreshing for a serious undergrad math class.
I would recommend taking it if you are interested in the topic. If you are willing to learn and ask questions, you will do well.
